biz.gabrys.easybundle

Class MultiplePropertyResourceBundleFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • biz.gabrys.easybundle.MultiplePropertyResourceBundleFactory
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    BundleFactory

    public class MultiplePropertyResourceBundleFactory
extends Object
implements BundleFactory

    Standard implementation of BundleFactory which store translations in multiple properties files (one per bundle). The name of the property file must be the same as the interface's name (plus additional information about locale). Correct hierarchy of file names:

    1. interfaceName_language_country_variant.properties
    2. interfaceName_language_country.properties
    3. interfaceName_language.properties
    4. interfaceName.properties

    Example: Messages is an interface.

    • Messages_pl_PL_WINDOWS.properties
    • Messages_pl_PL.properties
    • Messages_pl.properties
    • Messages.properties

    The property file name should be localized at the same package as the user specified interface.

    Example: If full name for the user specified interface is equal org.example.Message, then the property file should be localized in the directory example which is subdirectory of org.

    The content of the property file should have the following structure: 

     #comment are available
 key1=value1
 key2=value2
 key3=value3

    Example: 

     title=Bundle Factory 
 topic=How to create property file
 #comment
 copyrightInformation=Copyright@ 2013, All rights Reserved

    How to use the factory: 

     public interface Messages {
  
      String getTitle();
      
      String getTopic();
      
      String getCopyrightInformation();
 }
 
 final BundleFactory factory = new MultiplePropertyResourceBundleFactory();
 final Messages bundle = (Messages) factory.create(Messages.class, Locale.getDefault());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTitle());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTopic());
 System.out.println(bundle.getCopyrightInformation());

    will return: 

     Bundle Factory
 How to create property file
 Copyright@ 2013, All rights Reserved

    The factory creates a hierarchy of bundles which allows the sharing of values. This functionality will be presented on the following example.

    Example: An user defined two bundles Messages.properties and Messages_pl.properties. The files content is equal:

    • Messages.properties: 
       name=Name
 topic=default
    • Messages_pl.properties: 
       name=Nazwa
 #topic is undefined

    When the user will execute the following code: 

     final BundleFactory factory = new MultiplePropertyResourceBundleFactory();
 Messages bundle = (Messages) factory.create(Messages.class, Locale.ENGLISH);
 System.out.println(bundle.getName());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTopic());
 bundle = (Messages) factory.create(Messages.class, new Locale("pl"));
 System.out.println(bundle.getName());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTopic());

    He will get the following results: 

     Name
 default
 Nazwa
 default
    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    BundleValidator, PropertyResourceBundleFactory

    • Method Detail

      • create

        public Bundle create(Class<?> interfaceClass,
                     Locale locale)
        Creates a new instance of Bundle which implements interface interfaceClass.
        Specified by:
        create in interface BundleFactory
        Parameters:
        interfaceClass - the bundle interface class which defines getters methods.
        locale - the locale for which a bundle is desired.
        Returns:
        a new instance of Bundle.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the interface class is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the locale is null.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        BundleValidator.validateInterface(Class)
